metDecl.p:
The ābhāṇaka or rāsaka meter:
matta hohi caürāsī cahu paya cāri kala te saṭhi joṇi nibaṃdhī jāṇahu cahu a dala |
paṃcakkalu vajjijjahu gaṇu suṭṭhuvi gaṇahu so vi āhāṇaü chaṃdu ke vi rāsaü muṇahu ||

The bhramarāvali is a Prakrit meter that is composed, like the Nandini, of four lines that simply repeat the metrical unit sa (LLG), in this case five times, for a total of fifteen syllables per line (LLG LLG LLG LLG LLG), or 60 syllables in total.

The dohā meter is composed of four short quarters. The odd and even quarters in a line contain 13 and 11 mātrās, respectively. The even quarters of a dohā must end in a group of three mātrās, usually a heavy syllable followed by a light syllable. Moreover, this three-mātrā unit rhymes between the second quarter and the fourth (i.e., between the first and second line).

The gāthā is the most common meter of Prakrit poetry. It consists of two lines which are each composed of seven and a half alternating groups (gaṇas) of syllables. Each of these group (gaṇa) must add up to four moras (or mātrās). The odd groups (i.e., gaṇas 1, 3, 5, and 7) must not contain a ‘syncopated’ rhythm, that is, LGL or L|LLL (the latter stands for four light syllables with a word break between the first and the second, which causes the gaṇa to be parsed as syncopated rather than unsyncopated). Additionally, the sixth group of the first line must be syncopated. The line ends in a ‘half’ group, which is always a single syllable (with the weight of two moras). The second line is identical to the first, except that the sixth group is made up a single light syllable rather than a group of syllables adding up to four moras.

The vastuka meter most commonly occurs in a strophic verse as the first ‘fragment’ (khañjaka). It is a mora-counting verse, consisting of four lines of twenty-four moras each. Like most mora-counting verses, it contains rhythmic units (gaṇas) which alternate between unsyncopated and syncopated forms. Here is the general schema:
There is usually a word-break after the eleventh and fourteenth moras, i.e., in the middle of, or after, the third (syncopated) gaṇa. Usually following the vastuka is an ullāla, which consists of two lines of twenty-eight moras each, in the following pattern:

The nandinī is a syllable-counting meter that is made up of four lines with twelve syllables per line (hence 48 syllables in total) by repeating the sa pattern four times, hence: LLG LLG LLG LLG. The Bhramarāvalī is a closely-related meter that repeats the unit sa one more time.

tasutanu aṇuaṃciaṃcu paluṭṭipaluṭṭavi virahahavitaviyataviutaṇu, valivi pattapatti ṇiyabhuyaṇibhavaṇi visaṃṭhula vihalamaṇuvihvalamaṇa || 130 ||

note.p: 130 atha grīṣmartuvarṇanam kavir āha—ṇavagimha—he pathika! navagrīṣmāgame nāthaḥ pravasitaḥ, tadaivāñjaliṃ kṛtvā—hāsyanamaskāraṃ kṛtvā sukham api pravasitam | tadanu vyāghuṭya virahāgnitāpitatanuṣī visaṃsthula—vihalaṅghalamānasā gṛham āgatā || 130 ||

130 atha grīṣmatvaṃ vyācakhyāsur āha—ṇavagimhā—he pathika! navagrīṣmakālāgame nāthaḥ pravaśisitaḥ | tadaivāñjaliṃ kṛtvā—hāsyanamaskāraṃ kṛtvā sukham api pravaśisitam | tadanu vyāghuṭya virahāgnitāpitatanuṣī visaṃsthula vihalaṅghalamānasā gṛham āgatā ||

note.ab:
When my husband left at the beginning of the summer,
all my happiness said “goodbye” and took off.
I got up, then fell, my body burned by separation's fire.
I turned back and got home, destroyed and distressed in my mind.

visamajhāla jhalakaṃta jalaṃtiya tivvayara, mahiyalimahiyala vaṇatiṇadahaṇa tavaṃtiya taraṇikarativvakara || 131 ||

note.p: 131 tathā aratiṃ raṇaraṇakaṃ asukkhaṃkhaṃ ca sahantyā mama madanārttāyā malayasamīraṇo duḥsaho babhūva | tathā taraṇikarā viṣamajvālayā jvalantamahītalavanatṛṇadāhakās tapante || 131 ||

I was so utterly exposed to longing and unhappiness that I couldn't even bear the southern breezes, overcome by love. The harsh wind blows, I feel even sharper pain, there are grass-fires on the ground, and the sun's rays burn.

lg.l: jamajīhaha ṇaṃ caṃcalu ṇahayaluṇahīyalu lahalahaï, taḍataḍayaḍataḍiiḍi dhara tiḍaï ṇatuḍavvaṇuphuraï ṇa teyahatehayateaha bharu sahaï |
aïunhaü vomayaliḍomayali pahaṃjaṇu jaṃ vahaïvahaiṃ, taṃ jhaṃkharu virahiṇihivirahiṇīhivirahiṇiaṃgu aṃgu pharisiupharasiupharisaü dahaï || 132 ||

note.p: 132 vitarke cañcalaṃ nabhastalaṃ yamajihvāvallahalahati | traḍatraḍatraḍiti dharā suśuṣyantī—śabdaṃ karoti | tejobharaṃ na sahate | atyuṣṇaḥ prabhañjano vahati | jhaṃkharo ḍuḍuṃyālakanāmā pavanaḥ virahiṇīnām aṅgaṃ spṛṣṭā dahati || 132 ||

132 vitarke—cañcalaṃ nabhastalaṃ yamajihvāvat lahalahati | traḍatraḍatraḍiti dharā śuṣyantī—śabdaṃ karoti | tejobharaṃ na sahate | atyuṇyaatyuṣṇaḥ prabhañjano vyomatale vahati | jhaṃkharo ḍuṇḍuyālakanāmā pavanaḥ virahiṇīnām aṅgaṃ spṛṣṭā dahati || 132 ||

The sky is constantly waving, like the tongue of death, the earth is crackling—it can't stand the enormous heat—and when the blazing windstorm comes in the sky, it burns the bodies of women suffering in love like a tree.

note.p: 133–134 navaghanotkaṇṭhitaiś cātakaiḥ “priya priya” iti śabdo bhaṇyate sma | taraṅgiṇīṣu salilapravāhahaḥtucchācchacchaḥ sarati sma | atha ṣaṭsu padeṣu sahakāravarṇanam—phalabhāreṇonnamitaṃ śubhaṃ sahakāravanaṃ atisacchāyati—adhikaṃ śobhate | anyacca—yatra kuñjaraśravaṇasadṛkṣeṣu gandhavahena prakampiteṣu āmnapatreṣu, cūtotkaṇṭhitā saṃsargiṇī parivāritā preṅkholantī kīrapaṅktir varttate | tataḥ karuṇadhvaniḥ samutthitā | tāṃ śrutvā ’haṃ nissādhārā jātā | tanmanye he pathika! sarvarañjakenāhaṃ virañjitā || 133–134 ||

133–134 navaghanotkaṇṭhitaiś cātakaiḥ “priya priya” iti śabdo bhaṇyate sma | taraṅgiṇīṣu salilapravāhahaḥtucchācchas sarati sma | atha ṣaṭsu padeṣu sahakāravarṇanam—phalabhāreṇonnamitaṃ śubhaṃ sahakāravanaṃ atisacchāyam adhikaṃ śobhate | anyacca—yatra kuñjaraśravaṇasadṛśeṣu gandhavahena prakampiteṣu āmnapatreṣu cūtotkaṇṭhitā saṃsargiṇī parivāritā preṅkholantī kīrapaṅktir varttate | tataḥ karuṇadhvaniḥ samutthitā | tāṃ śrutvā ahaṃ nirādhārā jātā | tanmenmanye he pathika! sarvarañjakena ahaṃ virañjitā || yugmam ||

The cātaka birds say “piu,” waiting for the first clouds; the waters just trickle slightly in the riverbeds. The mango trees are bent down with the weight of their fruits, and offer pleasant shade, waving in the breeze like the ears of elephants; among its leaves have come together a flock of parrots, and rest there huddled close. The mango shoots are waving, and a plaintive note comes out: I am helpless (nissāhāra), O traveller, in this mango-grove.

135 haricandanaṃ yatsailāyacchaityārthe urasi lepitaṃ tadapyahisevitatvāt kucau tāpayati | tathā vividhaṃ vilapantyā hāralatā kusumamālā ca śaityārthe urasi nyaste, te api jvālāṃ muñcataḥ | tataḥ maraṇaśaṅkinī sabhayā jātā ||

The sandal paste that I spread on my breasts to cool them heated them even more, as if it were still full of snakes. Then, moaning so many things, I put necklaces of pearls and garlands of flowers there, but they too gave off heat. Then I became afraid.

ima sijjaha uṭṭhaṃta paḍaṃta salajjirihiṃsalajjarihiṃ, paḍhiu vatthu taha dohaüdūhaḍa pahiya saggaggirihiṃsagiggirahiṃ || 136 ||

note.p: 136 nisiśi śarīrasukhārthe kamaladalaprastaraṇaṃ kṛtam tadapi dviguṇam udvegaṃ karoti | evaṃ saśayyātaḥ uttiṣṭantyā, nirbalatvāt tatraiva patantyā, vastuko dodhakaś ca salajjayā sagadgadgirā paṭhitaḥ || 136 ||

136 niśāśi rātrai śayanīye śarīrasukhajjanakaṃ yas kamaladalasrastaraṇaṃ kṛtaṃ tad dviguṇam udvegaṃ karoti | evaṃ śahyāyyāyā uttiṣṭantyā salajjayā sagadgadaṃ yathā bhavati tathā vastuko dodhakaś ca mayā paṭhitaḥ ||

The cover of lotus-petals which I laid out on my bed at night to comfort my body made me even more distressed, so I got up from my bed but fell back down again, and in a shameful stammer and I said this vastu and dohā, O traveller.

note.p: 137 araviya—aravindāni ravikaraiḥ vikasāpitāni, tapanaguṇatvāt, tapanti, ity api | amṛtamayūṣokho viṣeṇa saha janmatvāt asukhaṃ janayati | caśabdād dāhayati ca | candanaṃ bhujaṅgadaśanaiḥ daṣṭam, ato ’ṅgaṃ kṣikṣapayati | hāraḥ kṣārodbhavaḥ, ato ’ṅgaṃ kṣikṣapati | keṣāṃ kusumasaśarakṣatānām | rājīva-candra-candana-ratnāni śiśirāṇi ucyante, paraṃ virahāgnijvālā kenāpi na vidhyāti, ataḥ punar aṅgāni parihiṃsyante || 137 ||

137 aravindāni ravikarait vikasāpitāni, tapanaguṇatvāt, tapanti ity api | amṛtamayūkho viṣeṇa saha janmatvāt asukhaṃ janayati dāhayati ca | candanaṃ bhujaṅgadaśanair daṣṭam ataḥ aṅgaṃ kṣapayati | hāraḥ kṣārodbhavaḥ, ato ’ṅgaṃ kṣipati, keṣāṃ kusumaśarakṣatānām | rājīva-candra-candana-ratnāni śiśirāṇy ucyante, paraṃ virahāgnijvālā kenāpi na vidhyāti | ato aṅgāni parihiṃsyante ||

Flowers are made to blossom by the rays of the sun: they burn with its heat. The rays of the moon can't produce pleasure: they burn with the poison it was born with. Sandal burns the body, bitten by the bites of a snake. Pearls, produced from salt, only pour it into the entry-wounds of love's flower-arrows. Flowers, the moon, sandal, gems are praised for being cool on earth, but they can't put out the fire of separation. No, they only afflict the body more.

Bhayani compares this verse to the following lines of Puṣpadanta’s Mahāpurāṇa:
sīyalu visu visu ṣa ṇa saṃti jaṇaï
hariyaṃdaṇu sihikulu aṃgu chaṇaï
ṇaliṇu vi sūrahu sayaṇattu vahaï
sayaṇīyali ghittaü dehu ḍahaï
The first portion (khañjaka appears not to be a vastu or kāvya, but a regular ābhāṇaka, although the text is in need of restoration.

138 etad alīkaṃ yad virahārttā tanuḥ = śarīraṃ ghanasāreṇa = karpūreṇa candanen carcayantī — limpayantī | punar viarahāgniḥ priyeṇaiva nirbhṛtaṃ vidhyāti || iti grīṣmavarṇanā samāptā ||

note.ab:
People smear their bodies with camphor and sandal in vain.
No, only the beloved can put out the fire of separation, there can be no doubt.

note.ab:
In this way I somehow managed to get through the summer,
which was really hot. Traveller, the rains then arrived:
what didn’t arrive was that heartless husband of mine.
In all four directions a terrifying and heavy darkness appeared.
A cloud was rumbling deeply and angrily in the sky.

note.ab:
The pathways can be seen only when the terrifying lightning
courses in the sky, cracking with a flash.
The pipīhā birds call out sweetly.
They are finally satisfied by the waters.
A line of herons appears in the sky,
flying along the surface of a monsoon cloud.

note.p: 141 grīṣmatapanakharataptakiraṇotkarṣasambandhi payaḥ puṣkarāt patat puṣkaraṇīṣu na māti | yataḥ—sahasraguṇamucchaṣṭutsraṣṭum ādataṃtte hi rasaṃ raviḥ | tathā ca pathi pravasantaḥ pathikāḥ payobhiḥ padatrāṇahastāḥ kṛtāḥ | gagane vidyutā karalaḥ pagadaṇḍako dṛśyate, nānyathā || 141 ||

Heated very harshly by the heat of the summer
through the very many rays [of the sun],
the water then falls from the clouds
and cannot be contained by the rivers.
[By the rivers], which are flowing onto the road,
Travellers are made to take their sandals in their hands.
At every step, the path only becomes visible
as [lightning] courses through the sky.

note.ab:
Coming together with constant surges, following hard and fast,
such that they were impossible to cross,
the roaring rivers gurgled [kari karayalu?].
All around, travellers were stopped in their tracks.
And for those who absolutely had to go on their way,
they could only go by boat, traveller, not by horse.

This verse uses a number of feminine adjectival formations that show the lengthening typical of Apabhramsha, where -aï (or -yaï) is added onto a stem that is ‘already’ feminine (often made even more expressly feminine by the use of the ending ī rather than ā).

There are also a number of possible cases of ‘group flexion,’ where ergative/instrumental marking occurs only on the last nominal form in a phrase (e.g., not on aṇimisaṇayaṇuvvinniya, but on jaggaṃtiyaï).

kimakivaṃ sahaüsahiu pahiya siharaṭṭhiyayasiharaṭṭhiyaïsihayaraṭṭhiyaï dusahaüdusahaü koila rasahiṃrasaï saru || 148 ||

note.p: 148 bho pathika! śyāmabahalaiḥ daśadiśiṃ vyāpya ākāśa ācchāditaḥ | gagane unnavimito ghurahurati ghano meghaḥ kṛṣṇāḍambaraḥ | ākāśamārgge nabhovallīvidyut taḍataḍeti śabdaṃ karoti | dardurāṇāṃ raṭanaṃ—pūtkāraṃ śrutvā sahyasoḍhuṃ na śakyate | bho pathika! nibiḍaṃ ca śabdābdād durddharaṃ nīradharaṃ meghaṃ siṣaśikharasthitena tena kathaṃ sahitam || 148 ||

148 varrdalena tamo atyarthaṃ jhampitvā—ākramya, dasaśasu dikṣu ambaram ākāśam ācchāditam | puna unnamito ghoraṃ yathā kṛṣṇāḍambaraṃ ghuruharati—garjati | nabhovallī—vidyut nabhomārge taralaṃ yathā taḍatkāraṃ kṛtvā—taḍatkaroti | dardurāṇāṃ raṭanaṃ raudraṃ śabdaṃ ko ’pi soḍhuṃ na śaknoti | nibiḍaṃ nirantaraṃ nīradharaṃ meghaṃ durdharadhāraughabharaṃ he pathika! kathaṃ sahāmi? | anyacca, śikharasthitā āmroparisthā kokilā duḥsahaṃ svaraṃ rasati ||

note.ab:
The dark storm clouds covered the sky and blocked it as far as the eye can see;
a frightful thick black mass rumbles up on high.
Streaks of lightning cracked suddenly and lit up the expanse of the sky.
Nobody can bear the terrifying sound of the croaking frogs.
The clouds—thick, without a break between them,
with torrents of water that are impossible to withstand—
how could I stand a chance against them, traveller?
The cuckoos kept making an insufferable din in the boughs of the trees.

list.item: Ktvā of jhaṃp- (deśī) ‘cover’
list.label: vaddaliṇa
list.item: < vārdala ‘storm-cloud’

list.item: onomatopoetic, with ghoru ghaṇu in a kind of ‘internal accusative’ construction
list.label: duddura-
list.item: < dardura- ‘frog’
list.label: kima
list.item: interrogative adverb of manner, formed on the basis of ima (< evam)

lg.l: ulhaviyaṃ gimhahavī dhārānivaheṇa pāusepāvaso pattepaüsopatto |
accariyaṃ mahamiha hiyaecitte hiyae virahaggī tavaï ahiyayaroahiyayaraṃ || 149 ||

note.p: 149 mayā grīṣmāṣmo ṛtuḥ nirgamitātāḥ | meghasamūhe varṣākāle prāpte śasati maha—mama hrihṛdaye etad āścaryaṃ tathāpi adhikatarāro virahāgnis tapati || 149 ||
149 he pathika! grīṣmahaviḥ pāuse—varṣākāle prāpte sati dhārānivahena meghadhārāsamūhena vyāpitam | paraṃ mama hṛdaya etad āścaryaṃ virahāgnir adhikataras tapati ||
The summer fires were put out by downpours when the rains arrived. But it’s amazing that the fire of separate burns even more forcefully in my heart.

list.label: ulhaviyaṃ
list.item: < ulh-av- (causative, deśī) ‘put out, extinguish [with water]’
Note that this gāthā, as is usual for verses in this meter, is in Prakrit.

lg.l: guṇaṇihi jalabiṃdubbhavahibiṃdubbhavihibiṃdubbhavaṇubiṃbubbhavaṇi, ṇa galatthiya lajjaṃti |
pahiya jaṃpaṃiya jaṃpāiya jaṃ thorasuihisuyahi, thaṇa thaḍḍhāthaṇa ghaṭṭhā ḍajjhaṃtijjhaṃti || 150 ||

note.p: 150 guṇayukyā jalabindūdbhavā muktāhārāḥ kiṃ na lajjantinte | yat pathika! stanau sthūlāśrubhir dahyete, paraṃ na lajjataḥ | yatataḥ stabdhau | stabdhānāṃ kaṣṭe ’pi sajjanānāṃ duḥkhaṃ lajjā ca na bhavati || 150 ||

150 guṇayukyā jalabindūdbhavā muktāhārārāḥ kiṃ na lajjante? | yat pathika! stanau sthūlāśrubhir dahyete, paraṃ na lajjataḥ | yataḥ stabdhau | stabdhānāṃ kaṣṭe ’pi sajjanānāṃ duḥkhaṃ lajjā ca na bhavati ||

Since they were not ashamed to be embraced by men who, full of good qualities, nevertheless produced tears, [alternatively: since they were not ashamed to be clapsed with pearls on a string that were produced from drops of water,] now they are burning with heavy teardrops, these hard [alternatively: obstinate] breasts.

list.label: guṇaṇihi
list.item: < guṇin-?
list.label: galatthiya
list.item: < gala-sthita-, ‘put on the neck,’ ‘embraced’
list.label: thora-
list.item: < sthūla-
list.label: thaḍḍhā
list.item: < stabdha-

The verse is a śleṣa/riddle. Maybe the sense is: even though they were ashamed when they weren’t embraced by rich men (or pearls), now they are covered with heavy tears (which have the same aqueous qualities as pearls) and it does no good.

lg.l: dohaü eu paḍheviṇu virahakheālasīivirahikhiā, u aggaïāgaï aïkhinnīkhinniya mohaparāvasīivasī |
suviṇaṃtari cirucira pavasiupavasiyaü jaṃja joiaüjoiu piu, saṃjāṇivisiṃjāṇavisijjāṇivi kara gahivigahavi maïtāma maïtattha ima bhaṇiubhaṇiyaü ihuiu || 151 ||

note.p: 151 etad dodhakaṃ paṭhitvā, virahākulā jātā | evam—amunā prakāreṇa, mohaparavaśā satī ciraṃ prasthito bharttā mayā svapne dṛṣṭaḥ | iti vacanaṃ kathithayitvā karagrahaṇapūrvvakaṃ evaṃ pathiko bhaṇitaḥ—evaṃ jñātvā kare gṛhītaḥ | satītvam iti sūcitam || 151 ||
151 etad dodhakaṃ paṭhitvā virahakhedālasayātikhinnayā mohaparavaśayā svapnāntare cirapravisavasitaḥ priyo dṛṣṭaḥ | upalakṣya, kare gṛhītvā, mayā evaṃ bhaṇitaḥ ||

After reciting this dohā, I was exhausted by the weariness of separation; oh, I was in such distress that I fell into the grip of delusion: when, in a dream, I beheld my beloved on his trip for a long while, I recognized him, took his hand, and said this to him:

list.label: virahakheālasīi
list.item: < viraha-kheda-ālasa with a ‘double’ feminine suffix
list.label: u
list.item: taken by the ṭippanaka as amunā prakāreṇa, but probably just an exclamation of sorrow.
list.label: aggaï
list.item: < agra-, ‘thereafter’ (Hindi āge)
list.label: joiaü
list.item: Kta of jo ‘see’ (from Skt. dyot-)
list.label: ihu
list.item: probably from idam

lg.l: kiṃ juttaṃyuttaṃ sukulaggasukalaggakulaggayāṇa muttūṇa jaṃ caci iha samae |
taḍataḍaṇativvaghaṇaghaḍaṇasaṃkule daïyadayīya vaccaṃti || 152 ||

note.p: 152 he dayita! kiṃ sukulodgatānāṃ idaṃ yuktam, yat taḍataḍaṇatīvrāyāṃ vidyuti ghanaghaṭanameghaśabdasaṃkule īdṛśe samaye dayitāṃ muktvā vrajanti || 152 ||
152 he dayite! kiṃ kulodbhavānām idaṃ yuktam, yat taḍataḍaṇatīvrāyāṃ vidyuti, ghanaghaṭanameghaśabdasaṃkule īdṛśe samaeye dayitāṃ muktvā vrajanti | tan na yutkam ||
Beloved! It is right, for people born into good families, to leave [their families] and set out at this time, which is full of thunder and the thick cover of stormclouds?

list.item: Note that this verse is in Prakrit.
The first verse also has a metrical defect that suggests the reading sukuloggaaāṇāṃ. In any case, the genitive may be construed with muttūṇa.

lg.l: ṇavamehamālāmāliya ṇahammi suracāvasuracāyasuracāi rattadisidisa pasaro |
ghanachannachamma iṃdoiehicchammaidevaehi piya pāvasaṃpiu pāusaṃ dusahaṃ || 153 ||

note.p: 153 he priya! prāvṛḍ—varṣākālo dussahaḥ | kaiḥ? meghamālā—suracāpendragopakaiḥ, āraktadaśadigprasāraiḥ — ity ādi meghālaṅkāraiḥ || 153 ||
153 he priya! prāvṛḍ duḥsahaḥ | kair navameghamālā-suracāpendragopakaiḥ | kiṃviśiṣṭais taiḥ? — diśi prasṛtaiḥ | punaḥ kaiḥ? — ghanacchanncchadmendubhiḥ ||
The spread into the red horizons of the rainbow in the sky, which is covered by series of stormclouds. With fireflies forming a thick covering, beloved, the rains are hard to bear.

list.item: Note that this verse is in Prakrit.
Probably suracāva-ratta-disi-pasaro is a compound, although the syntax of the verse seems a little loose.

lg.l: rāyarajjaruddharuddhukaṃṭhaggi viuddhīvibuddhī jaṃ sivaṇisavaṇisiviṇi, kaha haüṃ kaha piupiya pattharaṃgipattharaggi jaṃ na muiyamuī khaṇi |
jaïjaṃ ṇahuṇaṃ ṇiggaü jīujīvu pāvabaṃdhihi jaḍiu, hiyaü na kiṇakiṇi kirikirakari phuṭṭaü ṇaṃ vajjihi ghaḍiu || 154

note.p: 154 rāgaruddhakaṇṭhāgrā svapne prabuddhya yadā paśyāmi, kva aham, kva priya? tajjñātvā yan na mṛtā tanmanye prastarāṅgī | yajjīvo na nirgatas tanmanye pāpajaṭitaḥ | yacca hihṛdayaṃ na sphuṭitaṃ tanmanye vajraghaṭitam || 154 ||

154 rāgaruddhakaṇṭhāgrā svapne prabuddhya yadā paśyāmi, kva aham, kva priya? taṃtad jñātvā yan na mṛtā tanmanye prastarāṅgī | yajjīvo na nirgatas tanmanye pāpajaṭitaḥ | yacca hṛdayaṃ na sphuṭitaṃ tanmanye vajraghaṭitam ||

When I awoke from the dream, my throat choked with emotion, I wondered where I was and where my lover was. I must be made of stone, that I did not die at that moment. If my life did not leave, it is because it was transfixed by the bonds of sin. If my heart did not break, it is only because it is, as it were, made of diamond.

list.label: viuddhī
list.item: < vibuddha- (again with ṄīP and svārthe-ka, but here contracted)
list.label: kiṇa
list.item: probably a polarity marker (‘if it was not broken by anything’ = ‘if it was not broken at all’)
list.label: kiri
list.item: < kila ‘it must be the case’ (particle for something the speaker hasn’t personally witnessed)
list.label: ṇaṃ
list.item: particle of comparison (‘as it were’)

lg.l: īsarasari sālūrivasālūra kuṇaṃtī karuṇasari |
ihu dohaü maï paḍhiyaüpatthiupaḍhiu nisahaṇisi pacchimapahari || 155 ||

note.p: 155 īṣat svareṇa śālūravat karuṇaṃ svaraṃ kurvatīntyā eṣa dodhako mayā paṭhitaḥ, rātrau śeṣavibhāge || 155 ||
155 īṣat svareṇa śālūravat—maṇḍūkavat karuṇaṃ svaraṃ kurvantyā niśaḥ paścimaprahare eṣa dodhako mayā paṭhitaḥ ||
In plaintive tones, making a low noise, as if I were a frog, I recited this dohā in the last watch of the night.

list.label: īsarasari
list.item: taken as īṣat-svareṇa, but probably īṣat-rasara- (with -ara- as a kind of kṛt-suffix, ‘making a low noise’)

lg.l: jāmiṇi jaṃ vayaṇijjavayaṇajjavayaṇajju tua, taṃ tihuyaṇi ṇahu māimāiṃ |
dukkhihi hoi caüggaṇī, jhijjaïjhijjaü suhasaṃgāisaṃgāiṃ || 156 ||

note.p: 156 he yāmini! yat tava vacanīyaṃ tat tribhuvane ’pi na māti | eṣā rajanī durikaduḥkhitānāṃ caturguṇī bhavati | sukhasaṅgame tat kṣaṇād vrajati || 156 || varṣāvarṇanaṃ samāptam ||
156 he yāmini! yat tava vacanīyaṃ tat tribhuvane ’pi na māti | duḥkhe caturguṇā bhavasi | sukhe kṣaṇāt tvaṃ kṣīyase | varṣāvarṇanaṃ samāptam ||
Oh night! My reproach for you cannot be contained in all the three worlds: in suffering, you expand fourfold, but in happiness, you are much reduced.

list.label: jhijjaï
list.item: < *gži ‘be reduced, waste away’ (Skt. kṣiyate)

lg.l: imaiva vilavaṃtīvilavatavilaṃvaṃta kahava diṇadiṇu pāiu, geugeya giraṃta paḍhaṃtaha pāiu |
piyaaṇurāiaṇurāiya rayaṇiarayaṇi ramaṇīyavaramaṇiiva, gijjaïmuṇiyaṇajjaï pahiya muṇiyagīyaï aramaṇīyava || 157 ||

note.p: 157 atha śaradvarṇanam—evaṃ vilapantyā gītaṃ rāgeṇa gāyantyā, prākṛtaṃ paṭhantyā, varṣāprāntadinaṃ samāptam | yasmin rajanī ramaṇīkaiva gīyate, sā rajanī mayāmama aramaṇir iva — karapatrakam iva jātā || 157 ||
157 atha śarad—evaṃ vilavapantyā gītaṃ rāgeṇa gāyantyā, prākṛtaṃ paṭhantyā, varṣāprāntadinaṃ prāptam | yasmin rajanī ramaṇīkaiva gīyate, sā rajanī mayā aramaṇir iva — karapatram iva jātā ||
With these words, somehow the [final] day arrived, as I sang songs, and recited Prakrit, with love for my beloved. The night is said to be lovely, but know, traveller, that it was like an axe.

list.label: pāiu
list.item: < prāpita- and prākṛta-
list.label: ramaṇīyava
list.item: < ramaṇīyaka-, but perhaps the va is to avoid the ending yaya
list.label: muṇiya
list.item: < muṇi- (deśī) ‘know’
list.label: aramaṇīyava
list.item: ‘axe’ (deśī?); the va might stand for iva

lg.l: jāmiṇijāmiṇī gamiyaï ima jaggaṃtahajāgaṃtahaṃ, pahiya piyāgamipiyāgama asaaïsaāsa tagaṃtahatagaṃtahaṃ |
gosuyaraṃtagosayaraṃtagosapasaṃrata milhi sijjāsaṇu, maṇi sumaraṃtasuyaraṃta virahaṇinnāsuṇu || 158 ||

note.p: 158 evaṃ priyāgamāsaśayā jīvantyā gose=prabhāte śayyāsanaṃ muktvā virahanāśanaṃ priyaṃ smarantyā jāgrantyātyā rātrir gamitā || 158 ||
158 evaṃ priyāgamāśayā jīvantyā gose=prabhāte śayyāsanaṃ muktvā virahanāśanaṃ priyaṃ smarantyā jāgratyā rātrir nirgamitā ||
The night passed in this way as I remained awake, holding on to life, traveller, only because of my lover’s return. I left my bed at dawn, and thought of the jewel that can destroy separation:

list.label: tagaṃtaha
list.item: < tagg- (deśī) ‘remain alive’
list.label: gosuyaraṃta
list.item: < Prakrit gosa ‘dawn’ (derivation unclear)
list.label: maṇi
list.item: probably the sun, despite the commentaries taking it as priyam

lg.l: dakkhiṇadakṣiṇa maggu ṇiyaṃtaha bhattihiṃ, diṭṭhu aïtthiagatthirisiurisī maï jhattihiṃṣattihi |
muṇiyaümuṇiṇumuṇī su pāusu parigamiaüpuṇu gamiyaü, piu paraesi rahiu ṇahunaha || 159 ||

note.p: 159 patyāśritatvātvād dakṣiṇamārgaṃ bhaktyā paśyantyā agastimaharṣir dṛṣṭaḥ | varṣākālaṃ pararigamitaṃ jñātvā bharttā paradeśe sthitaḥ, paraṃ na ramitaḥ || 159 ||
159 patyāśritatvād dakṣiṇamārgaṃ bhaktyā paśyantyā agastimaharṣir jhaṭiti = śīghraṃ dṛṣṭaḥ | jñātaṃ varṣā parigamitā | paradeśe sthitaḥ priyahḥ sa na ramitaḥ ||
As I stared towards the south with devotion, I at once saw the great sage Agastya, and I know that those rains had passed. But my lover remained abroad. I did not have the enjoyment of him.

list.label: ṇiyaṃtaha
list.item: < ṇia- ‘look at’
list.label: maï
list.item: instr. of the first person pronoun (< mayā)

lg.l: gaya viddaraviviḍvaravividhyuravi valāhaya gayaṇihi, maṇahara rikkha paloiyapaïloiya rayaṇihi |
huyaü vāsubāsu chammayalichammayala phaṇiṃdaha, phuriya junhaphuirū junhu nisi nimmalacaṃdaha || 160 ||

note.p: 160 balāhakā gamaganād vidīrya gatā | rajanyāṃ manoharāṇi ṛkṣāṇi pralokitāni | phaṇīndrāṇāṃ pātāle vāso yājātāḥ | candrasya jyotsnā nirmalā jātā || 160 ||
160 balāhakā gaganānād vidīrya gatā | rajanyāṃ manoharāṇi ṛkṣāṇi pralokitāni | phaṇīndrāṇāṃ pātāle vāso jātāḥ | candrasya jyotsnā nirmalā sphuritā ||
The clouds broke up and left from the sky. The Pleiades were seen in the night. The serpents made their home on the surface of the earth. The light of the clear moon shimmered at night.

list.label: chammayali
list.item: < kṣmā-tala-

lg.l: sohaï salilusalila sarihiṃsarahiṃ sayavattihi, vivihataraṃga taraṃgiṇi jaṃtihi |
jaṃ haya hīya giṃbhiṇagaṃbhinagimhiṇavasarayaha, taṃ puṇi soha caḍī ṇava sarayaha || 161 ||

note.p: 161 śatapatraiḥ sarovareṣu śasisalilāni śobhante | taraṅgiṇīṣu gacchantas taraṅgāṅgāḥ śobhante | yā ca navasarasāṃ grīṣmeṇa sośobhā hṛtā sā śaradi caṭitā || 161 ||
161 śatapatraiḥ sarovareṣu salilāni śobhante | taraṅgiṇīṣu gacchantas taraṅgāḥ śobhante | yā ca navasarasāṃ grīṣmeṇa śobhā hṛtā sā śaradi caṭitā ||

The saptapatra leaves make the water in the ponds beautiful; the various waves in their course, the rivers. Though it was struck down from the fresh lakes by the summer, the beauty returned to them afresh.

list.label: caḍī
list.item: contracted form of caḍia < ‘rise up’ (cf. Hindi caṛhnā)
The figure of the first half-verse is dīpaka.

lg.l: haṃsihi kaṃduṭṭihikaṃduṭṭahikuṭiṭṭihi ghuṭṭivi rasu, kiyaükiu kalayalu sumaṇoharu sarasu |
ucchali bhuvaṇubhuvaṇi bhariya sayavattihiṁ, gaya jalarillirilla paḍilliya titthihiṁ || 163 ||

note.p: 162 haṃsaiḥ kamalakandotkaṇṭhitais teṣāṃ rasaṃ pītvā manoharakalakalaḥ kṛtaḥ | saśatapatraiḥ bhuvanaṃ bhṛtaṃ | jalapravāhas tīrthe svasthāne patitaḥ || 162 ||
162 haṃsaiḥ kamalakandotkaṇṭhitaiḥ teṣāṃ rasaṃ pītvā manoharaḥ kalakalaḥ kṛtaḥ | śatapatraiḥ bhuvanaṃ bhṛtaṃ | jalapravāhas tīrthe svasthāne patitaḥ ||

The geese drink up the liquid of the blue lotuses and make their honking even more charming and moving. The world is full of the lotuses which have spring up. Streams of water go and cascade over the crossings.

list.label: kaṃduṭṭihi
list.item: < kandoṭa- ‘blue lotus’ (looks like oblique functioning as genitive, or maybe vowel harmony)
list.label: ghuṭṭivi
list.item: < ghuṭṭ- (deśī) ‘drink, sip, consume’
list.label: ucchali
list.item: Ktvā of ucchal- ‘spring up’
list.label: jalarilla
list.item: jala with suffix -rilla, here fem.
list.label: paḍilliya
list.item: < pat ‘fall’, with -illa- suffix (here fem. extended), serving as a predicate

lg.l: dhavaliyapaḍilleyadhavalasaṃkhasaṃkāsihisaṃkāsaï, sohahi saraha tīratīrivīru saṃkāsihisaṃkāsaïṃ |
ṇimmalaṇīrasarihiṃ pavahaṃtihiṁ, taḍa rehaṃti vihaṃgamapaṃtihiṁrehaṃ vihagaṃ paṃtihi || 163 ||

note.p: 163 dhavalitasaṃṣaśaṃkhasaṃkāśaiḥ sarasāṃ taṭāḥ śobhante | nirmmalanīrasarasāṃ taṭā vihaṅgamapaṅktibhir upaviśadbhiḥ śobhante || 163 ||
163 dhavalitaśaṃkhasaṃkāśaiḥ sadṛkśaiḥ satkāśaiḥ sarasāṃ taṭāḥ śobhante | nirmalanīrasarasāṃ taṭā vihaṅgamapaṅktibhiḥ praviśadbhiḥ śobhante ||

The shores of the pond look beautiful with the kāśa-grass that looks as if it were whitened with white shells. The banks of the rivers with pure water look beautiful because of the flocks of birds that are flying past it.

list.label: saṃkāsihiṃ
list.item: in the first line it means ‘similar to’ (Skt. saṃkāśa-); in the second, it means kāśa-grass (‘good kāśa?)
list.label: sohahi
list.item: 3pl. < śubh-
Note that -hiṁ is instrumental in pavahaṃtihiṁ and vihaṃgamapaṃtihiṁ but genitive in ṇimmalaṇīrasarihiṃ.

lg.l: paḍibiṃbaüpaḍabiṃbaü darasijjaïdarisijjaï vimalihiṃ, kaddamakaddumabhāru pamukkiupamukkaü salilihiṃ |
sahami ṇa kuṃjasaddusadda sarayāgami, marami marālāgamimurālāgami ṇahu taggamitaggāgami || 164 ||

note.p: 164 pratibimbodayo nirmalo dṛśyate | salilair pānīyaiḥ kardamabhāraḥ pramukitaḥmukta | śaradāgame kuñjānāṃ pakṣiṇāṃ śabdo na śrūyate | tasyāgame kamalamṛṇālā api gatāḥ || 164 ||
164 salilair vimalaiḥ pratibimbaṃ dṛśyate | kardamabhāraś ca muktaḥ | krauñcaśabdaṃ na sahāmi | marālīgame ’game ca marāmi ||

Now that the mass of mud has disappeared, reflections can be seen in the clear waters. I can’t stand the sound of the Krauñca birds at the onset of autumn: I will die as soon as the marāla comes. I can’t go on.

list.label: darasijjaï
list.item: < dṛśyate
list.label: kuṃja
list.item: < krauñca- (note voicing after nasal)
list.label: taggami
list.item: < tagg- (deśī) ‘continue living’

lg.l: jhijjhaü pahiya jalihi jhijjhaṃtihi, khijjaü khajjoyahiṃkhajjoihiṃ khajjaṃtihi |
sārasa sarasusārasarasusārasu pharasu rasahiṁ kiṃ sārasi, mahamaïmama ciru jiṇṇadukkhujiṇṇadukkhadukkhuṃ jinna kiṃ sārasi || 165 ||

note.p: 165 sārasāḥ sarasaṃ rasanti | tadā mayotktam—he sārasi! mama cirajīrṇaduḥkhaṃ kiṃ smārayasi? keṣu satsu, jaleṣu kṣayatsu khadyoteṣu dyotatsu || 165 ||
165 sārasāḥ sarasaṃ rasanti | tadā mayoktaṃ—he sārasi! mama jīrṇaduḥkhaṃ kiṃ smārayasi? keṣu satsu?—jaleṣu kṣayatsu satsu, khadyoteṣu dyotatsu ||

As the waters recede, I too receded, traveller; As the fireflies flickered out, I become depressed. The Sārasa birds are honking passionately. Oh Sārasi! Why are you making me remember my pain, which after so long had started to subside?

list.item: < khajj- (deśī) ‘to become exhausted, worn-out, or old’

list.item: < smārayasi ‘cause to remember’ and the vocative of sārasī

lg.l: niṭṭhura karuṇukasaṇu saddu maṇamahi lavamaha na mahiṃ lavu, daḍḍhādaḍhādaṭṭhā mahila hoi gayamahilava |
ima ikkikkahaikkakkahaikkaṃkkaha karuṇa bhaṇaṃtaha, pahiya ṇaṇu kui dhīravaï khaṇaṃtahakuṇaṃtahaṃdhuraṃ taha || 166 ||

note.p: 166 he sārasi! niṣṭhuraṃ karuṇaśabdaṃ manomadhye lava | virahārttā strī tava śabdena gatamaholatsavā bhavantiti | evaṃ ekaṃ ekaṃ prati karuṇaśabdaṃ bhaṇantyā, tathāpi ko ’pi na dhīrayati || 166 ||
166 he sārasi! niṣṭhuraṃ karuṇaśabdaṃ manomadhye lava | virahārttā strī tava śabdena gatamahotsavā bhavati | evam ekam ekaṃ prati karuṇaśabdaṃ bhaṇantyā, tathāpi ko na dhīrayati ||

Keep your harsh and mournful song to yourself. A woman who is burned by it has nothing to rejoice about. I was saying this to each one of them, sorrowfully, but none of them made me feel better, traveller, for even a moment.

list.label: khaṇaṃtaha

lg.l: acchihiacchiiacchaya jiha sannihasannihisannayasaṇāha gharaghari kaṃtayakaṃtaï, racchihiracchaï ramihiramahi ti rāsu ramaṃtayabhamaṃtaya |
karivikaravi siṃgāru viviha āharaṇihiṃāharaṇahi, cittavicittaï taṇupaṃguraṇihipaṃguraṇahipaṃguraṇaï || 167 ||

note.p: 167 yāsāṃ strīṇāṃ saṃnidhau gṛhe kāntāḥ santi, rathyāsu rāsaṃ ramantyas tāḥ ramanti | vividhanānāprakāraiḥ siśṛṅgāraṃ kṛtvā ramanti | kaiḥ citravicitraśarīraprāvaraṇaiḥ || 167 ||
167 yāsāṃ strīṇāṃ saṃnidhau gṛhe kāntāḥ santi, tā rathyāsu rāsaṃ ramantyas bhramanti | vividhābharaṇaiḥ śṛṅgāraṃ kṛtvā, citravicitrais tanupaṅguraṇair vastraiś ca ||

Those women whose husbands are near them at home delight in the rāsa dance in the roads, delighting in dressing themselves well, with all kinds of adornments, and with fine garments that dazzled the mind.

list.label: taṇu-paṃguraṇihiṃ

lg.l: tilaütilu bhālayali turakkiturikki tilakkivi, kuṃkumi caṃdaṇi taṇu caccaṃkivi |
soraṃḍahiṃsoraṃḍihisoraṃḍaha karikiri liyahikarahi phiraṃtihiphiraṃtahithiraṃtiya, divvamaṇoharu geu giraṃtihigiraṃtahi || 168 || reads dhari dhari maṃgalu geu thavaṃtiya.

list.item: For the commentaries, translations and notes on this verse, which forms a yugma with the following verse, see the following verse.

lg.l: dhūva diṃti gurugurabhatti saïttihisuhatthihiṃ, goāsaṇihiṃ turaṃgacalatthivalacchihiṃ |
taṃ joivi haüṃhaü ṇiyayaniyaraniyaniru uvvinniyauvvinnī, ṇeyaṇiya sahiyapahiya mahahaü icchā punniyaunniya || 169 ||

note.p: 168–169 gavāsane turaṅgamasāśālāsu nāryo bhālasthale tilakaṃ tīkṣṇaṃ kṛtvā, kuṅkumacananābhyāṃ tanum arcayitvā, soraṇḍakaṃ = krīḍābhājanaṃ kare kṛtvā, divyaṃ gītaṃ gāyantyo gurarubhaktisahitā dhūpaṃ dadanti | taṃ soraṇḍakaṃ dṛṣṭvā udvignā jātā | yato necchā pūṛṇā || 168–169 ||

168–169 gavāsane turaṅgamaśālāsu nāryo bhālasthale tilakaṃ tīkṣṇaṃ kṛtvā, kuṅkumacananābhyāṃ tanum arcayitvā, soraṇḍakaṃ = krīḍābhājanaṃ kare kṛtvā, divyaṃ gītaṃ gāyantyo gurubhaktisahitā dhūpaṃ dadanti | taṃ soraṇḍakaṃ dṛṣṭvāham udvignā jātā | yato necchā pūṛṇā jātā ||

lg.l: taü pikkhiyapiyara disi ahiya vicittiyaahiya vicittayaahiyayara palhaṃtitha, ṇāya huāsaṇihutāsaṇi jaṇu pakkhittiyajaṇu pakhittayaari vi sutpitiyariujaṇi khittiya |
maṇimaṇa pajjaliya viraha jhālāvali, naṃdaṇinaṃdaṇa gāhagāhā bhamarāvali || 170 ||

note.p: 170 bhramarāvalyā eṣā nandiṇi gāthā bhaṇitā | tadā adhikavicitrāṃ diśaṃ preṣyakṣya jāne ahaṃ hutāśane prakṣiptā | kābhiḥ pravjvālitamanovirahajvālābhiḥ || 170 ||

170 tato diśo ’dhikavicitrā dṛṣṭā, aham evaṃ jāne hutāśane prakṣiptā | manasi virahajvālāvaliḥ prajvalitā | tā nandinī gāthā bhramarāvaliś ca bhaṇitā ||
bhagaṇā iha naṃdiṇi chaṃda dhuyaṃ, caüsaṭṭhi vi mattaya saṃṭhaviyaṃ |
guru solasa tīsa duī lahuyaṃ, aṭhatālisa akkhara baṃdhaviyaṃ || ||

Then, I looked and saw that the sky was even more wonderous: it was as if I had been hurled into the fire. In my heart the dull glow of separation burst into flames: here is a Nandinī, Gāthā, and Bhramarāvalī.

list.label: disi
list.item: a f. noun in the direct case (not loc. as in Skt.)

ṇāya ... jaṇu seem to mean (redundantly) ‘as if...’)

lg.l: sakasāya ṇavabbhisaṇasavvisanavabbisaṇicca bhisa suddhagale, dhayaraṭṭha-rahaṃgavihaṃga rasaṃti jale |
gayadaṃtigayadiṃti camakkariṇaṃ pavaraṃ, sarayāsari ṇevara jhīṇasaraṃ || 171 ||

note.p: 171 sakaṣāya sadviśāsvādaśuddhagalā dhṛtarāṣṭrā rathāṅgāś ca jale rasanti | gatiṃ camatkārakāriṇīṃ kurvanti | saśaratśriyo manye nūpuraṃ kṣīnasvaraṃ yathā varttate || 171 ||

naṃdaṇicchandaḥ | lakṣaṇaṃ yatḥā—
sagaṇā iha naṃdiṇi chaṃda dhuvaṃ, caüsaṭṭha vi matta gha saṃthaviyaṃ |
guru solasa tīsa duī lahuyaṃ, aṭhatālisa akkhara baṃdhaviyaṃ ||
171 sakaṣāya navabhisyasvādaśuddhagalā dhṛtarāṣṭrāś ca rathāṅgāś ca jale rasanti | gatiṃ camatkārakāriṇīṃ kurvanti | śaracchriyo manye nūpuraṃ kṣīṇasvaraṃ yathā vartate ||

The geese and the ducks are quacking in the waters, with throats that have been purified by new lotus-fibers, rich in astringent. They (gayadaṃti) in a way that is astounding and excellent. Against the beauty of autumn, anklets seem as if they can hardly make a noise.

list.label: gayadaṃti
list.item: unclear; Bhayani translates as ‘move,’ and Mayrhofer as ‘cry’ (the latter is contextually more appropriate).
list.label: sarayāsari
list.item: translated by the commentaries as śaracchrī, although perhaps it is from śarat-svare

lg.l: āsoe sarayasaraï mahāsarīesarīisirīe payakhalirakhāliraveyaviyaḍāeviyāḍāe |
sārasi rasiūṇa saraṃ puṇarutta ruyāviyāruyāviyaruyāviyā dukkhaṃ || 172 ||

note.p: 172 asvaśvini māse padaskhalitavegavikaṭāsu mahānadīṣu sārasena svaraṃ kṛtvā dukhaduḥkhaṃ yathā punaruktaṃ roditā || 172 ||
172 asviniāśvine māse padaskhalitavenagavikaṭāsu mahānadīṣu sārasena svaraṃ kṛtvā duḥkhaṃ yathā punaruktaṃ roditā ||

In the autumn month of Aśvin, in a great river, which was intimidating because of the stream that could cause one to tumble down, there was a sārasa bird which let out such a sound that I lamented my suffering all the more.

list.label: āsōe
list.item: < aśvayuk-
list.label: -khalira-
list.item: ‘causing to stumble’ (-ira- with the root skhal-).
list.label: ruyāviyā
list.item: ‘double’ causative of rud- ‘cry’
The language here is Prakrit, although a few words seem ‘Apabhraṃśa-ized’ (sārasi for sārasī, puṇarutta instead of puṇaruttaṃ).

lg.l: sasijunha-nisāsu susohiyayaṃsohiyayaṃsusohiyaṃsaṃsohiyaṃ dhavalaṃ, varatuṃgapayāra-maṇoharayaṃ amalaṃ |
piyavajjiya-sijja-lulaṃta pamukkaraepamukkharae, jamakuṭṭayamakuṭṭajammakucchi-sariccha vahāragaevihāṇievihāviya saraesurae || 173 ||

note.p: 173 śaratkāle śaśijyotsnayā nisāśāsu dhavalagṛhāṇi varatuṅgaprākārāṇi ca manoharāṇi jātāni | tathaiva priyavarjitāyāṃ mayi śayyāyāṃ lulantyāṃ yamakuṭṭasadṛkṣaṃ—antakaprahārasadṛśaṃ yathā vihitam || 173 ||
173 śaratkāle śaśijyotsnayā niśāsu dhavalagṛhāṇi varatuṅgaprākārāṇi ca manoharāṇi kṛtāni | tathaiva priyavarjitāyāṃ mayi śayyāyāṃ lulitaṃ yamakuṭṭasadṛkṣaṃ—antakaprahārasadṛśaṃ yathā vihitam ||

In moonlit nights, the mansions are dazzling beautiful, white and charming with their lofty ramparts, in the autumn which is free of dust, and which is deadly as Yama’s axe, if you are tossing and turning in a bed without your lover.

list.label: vahāragae
list.item: ? Mayrhofer gives ‘capable of killing’ (as if from vadh-).
list.label: lulaṃta
list.item: Unclear how this participle (from lul ‘toss and turn’) fits into the sentence.
list.label: kuṭṭa
list.item: ‘axe’ or ‘mace’ (cf. Sanskrit kuṭṭa- ‘breaking,’ only used at the end of a compound)
Note that this, too, is in Prakrit.

lg.l: acchihiatthihiacchaï jihajaha nārihiṃ nara ramiraïramiyaï, sohaï saraha tīritīra tihatihi bhamiraï |
bālayabālaï vara juvāṇa khillaṃtaya, dīsaïdīsahi ghari ghari paḍaha vajjaṃtaya || 174 ||

note.p: 174 atha kārtikavarṇanam—yāsāṃ strīṇāṃ narā ramatonto vartante, tābhiḥ bhramantībhiḥ sarasāṃ taṭāḥ śobhante | kiṃ kurvantyaḥ—navayauvanābhiḥ varabālābhiḥ krīḍantyaḥ | pratigṛhaṃ pratigṛhaṃ paṭahā vādyamānā dṛśyante || 174 ||
174 atha kārtikavarṇanam—yāsāṃ strīṇāṃ narā ramanto vartante, tābhir bhramantībhiḥ sarasāṃ taṭāḥ śobhante | bālakā javanajuvakavarāḥ krīḍanto dṛśyante | gṛhe gṛhe paṭahā vādyamānā dṛśyante ||
